paper_metadata.title: Amyloid Cardiomyopathy in Hereditary Transthyretin V30M Amyloidosis - Impact of Sex and Amyloid Fibril Composition
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR V30M variant in the context of amyloid cardiomyopathy, focusing on penetrance data and clinical characteristics of affected and unaffected carriers.

patients.demographics: 72 males and 35 females, mean age at onset 56 years
patients.phenotype: ATTR V30M amyloidosis with mixed phenotype including cardiac and neuropathic symptoms

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Virtually all males (97%) and the majority of women (73%) carrying type A fibrils had increased IVST (> 12 mm).
Among patients with type B fibrils, increased IVST was noted in 42% of males and 25% of females.

functional_data.summary: The TTR V30M variant leads to the formation of amyloid fibrils that cause cardiac and neuropathic symptoms.

variants.segregation_data: The variant segregates with disease in families, as shown by the familial clustering of symptoms.
variants.evidence_level: High, based on clinical data and previous studies.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the impact of sex and fibril composition on disease severity.
key_quotes: Patients carrying the TTR V30M mutation commonly show a mixed phenotype but with substantial variation in disease manifestations.
This study demonstrates a clear difference between sexes in the severity of amyloid heart disease in ATTR V30M amyloidosis patients.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical characteristics for male and female ATTR amyloidosis patients
Echocardiographic findings for patients grouped according to fibril type and sex

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear data on the TTR V30M variant.
